I'm an adult, and I love the Chips.  I am not the least bit embarrassed to admit it, heck, I am proud of it.  They are so cute, especially since they added the Chipettes.  I saw part of this movie on TV right before I was going on a business trip, and I had to buy a copy to watch while traveling.  I thought it was bright and funny and made me feel good after watching it, each time I watched it.  For some reason, the television rating for it is one-half star.  Wrong, wrong, wrong.  It's not for everyone.  It's not the greatest movie ever made.  If you are cynical and pessimistic, you might not care for it.  Or, it might just make you happier, like it did me (definitely a cynic and a pessimist).  Yes, it makes me happy, so five stars.  I have a big smile on my face just thinking about this movie.  Of the three A & the C movies I've seen (the original, Squeakquel, and Chipwrecked), this is my favorite.  I also loved Jenny Slate as Zoe.  I thought she was hilarious. If your kids -- or you -- enjoy innocent and very lighthearted fun, you'll love this movie. My 9-year-old son sure did. The songs range from the pretty-current (ones preteens today would know and love) to previous-generation favorites like the Go-Go's "Vacation." David Cross is great again as the villain, Ian, and the rest of the cast does very good work as well.

This is not art. It's not a deathless piece of cinema. Compared to "Citizen Kane," it deserves maybe one-and-a-half stars. But it is not trying to be "cinema" -- it's trying to be a zany, ridiculous child-friendly film about talking, singing chipmunks. It succeeds perfectly at that, so I have given it 5 stars for doing just what it set out to do. It's good clean fun that my boy really enjoyed. He laughed out loud at many points during the film, and because he loved it, I loved watching it with him.. If you are looking for something silly and predictable that contains nothing scary or "inappropriate," this is a very solid choice.

Alvin & the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked is really good.  You know, I'm surprised just how good it is.  As a kid of the 80's I loved the cartoon.  I loved the mischievous adventures that Alvin would get into.  I loved the way he'd always get under Dave's skin.  I loved the renditions of popular 80's songs such as the Cars "Shake It Up" and Madonna's "Material Girl", but these current movies are probably even better.  They step up the excitement level a few more notches.

This one is about Alvin and the gang getting stuck on a desert island after floating away on a kite.  Dave and their crooked manager from the previous films makes a return, and he's actually fairly tame, friendly, reasonable and likeable this time around.  The female chipmunks return as well.  Perhaps the only complaint I have (besides all the cheesy singing and dancing) is the constant need for the chipmunks to sing current music from the likes of Lady Gaga and Justin Bieber.  These songs won't last over the long term and therefore won't be remembered several years from now.  The writers should stick with the classics instead.

Anyway, when the chipmunks have to fend for themselves on a deserted island, this is when all chaos breaks loose.  They meet a woman who's been there for 7-8 years and well, she's mentally unstable and clearly lost her marbles!  She's there because she's on a quest for gold.  Meanwhile the chipmunks just want to be rescued.  They worry that Dave might not be coming, but... will he?  You'll have to watch it to find out!

Overall, pretty solid jokes (though a little more childish this time around) and great storytelling and entertainment for the entire family guaranteed (if you're a chipmunks fan, that is).  Perhaps the relationship between Alvin and Dave is more sentimental than usual as well.  Isn't Theodore just adorable?  Yes!  And the heroics of Simon as a result of a spider bite?  You'll understand what this means when you watch the film, haha.

Where the first Chipmunks movie was cute, I never really saw it as a multi-film franchise. Lo and behold, we're already at film three. Overall, Chipwrecked shows that there's still some life to the franchise, although probably not enough for a fourth movie. On the one hand, the Chipmunks themselves were as funny as ever. We actually see the characters develop and begin to poke fun at their stereotypes. I particularly loved how Simon went "nuts" and transformed into a French Rambo. The flirtation between Simon and Jeannette was adorable.

The human actors did disappoint. Dave is Dave and was fine for the most part. Ian returns wearing a funny pelican suit. Still, I feel like the writers didn't really squeeze out all of the humor they could have gotten out of that character (although his speech near the end was classic). The big disappointment was Zoey, Zoey is a new character, a castaway stuck on the island where the Chipmunks land. Aside from a few funny references to Tom Hanks' movie Cast Away - including sports balls with eyes and mouths - her character just doesn't add a whole lot to the movie. She seems awkward and out of place at times. At times, I kept wishing she would go away so the camera could focus on the Chipmunks. Fortunately, despite my complaints, she's actually not in too much of the movie, but it still would have been better to either make her do something important, make her funny, or make her go away.

Ultimately, I'm glad we got Chipmunks 3. If there's another one, I think it'll really have to focus on the Chipmunks and their humor, and leave the humans out of it.

Alvin, Simon, Theodore, Brittany, Jeanette, and Eleanor all become marooned on a desert island when another of Alvin's wild schemes goes awry, this time while on a vacation cruise to an international music awards show overseas. In an attempt to rescue them, Dave soon gets stranded too, and even evil "Uncle" Ian is along for the adventure. Meanwhile, the `munks are not in the best of hands, as they have fallen into a friendship of sorts with another castaway, a woman named Zoe who is clearly not all there and definitely not concerned with anyone's safety.

This third installment in the Chipmunks' bigscreen/live-action franchise was yet another huge hit, and that probably means those of us who enjoy the Chipmunks can look forward to another film down the pipeline (hopefully keeping Jason Lee and keeping to the bigscreen. However, this one has been hit pretty hard in the reviews department. People generally didn't like it and consider it a cheap, contrived cash grab. But, ya know what? A LOT of those people seem to say that about any live-action film with CGI cartoon stars, even without ever seeing the movie. It's a kinda prejudice that exists these days against certain kinds of movies, especially ones with the younger audience as priority. Yes, they are all cash grabs; that doesn't mean they can't be good films. And, you've also got tons of people out there who could never find this sort of thing entertaining because their brains are too "old". They see this as just a movie to take their kids to, and something they have to suffer through. They would never ALLOW themselves to enjoy it. So, all I'm saying is, be careful whose advice you take about ANY movie's worth. See it yourself, and if you know you're not going to like it because it is a Chipmunks movie or a live-action cartoon, or whatever else, before you even see the film, then even if you do see it, you might as well keep your opinion to yourself. Just because they are not your genre does not mean they are all garbage.

So, speaking to those who were open minded about the first film (which was a very good film, and any negatives I've heard on it came from people like I've described above or that breed of fan who thinks the 80's version of the Chipmunks IS and SHOULD ALWAYS BE the only way they are ever done), longtime Chipmunk fans like myself or not, this movie is NOT as bad as everyone has said. It's not as good as the first one, but I'd say it is as good as the second, and at least we don't get a replacement Dave here for the bulk of the film. Now, this film IS more pandering to the kid audience, as the second one was (this one might be worse in that department), and there are a few cringe-worthy moments of over-the-top silliness, like with the second film, which usually has to do with how some humans interact with the chipmunks. In this film, I was not crazy about the skanky club-girl dance off the Chipettes had early on. And, no doubt, a lot of people probably found the Zoe character a bit annoying. I think that she was supposed to be a little bit, but comedic personalities like her are often annoying to many people. She was still pretty funny. And the main characters, Dave, the Chipmunks, the Chipettes, and Ian were back in perfect form. If you're someone who watches this movie more for the Chipmunks than anything else, I'd take a guess that they get most of the screen time this go-round. But, like I said, we thankfully see a lot more of Dave, which the second film lacked.

Anyway, as for the story, yeah, it's pretty simple, and of course it's contrived. That's the nature of cartoon character stories, especially those largely rooted in the world of television. The entertainment comes from the characters, how they handle things, how they interact with others, etc... It's about personalities, and these characters are the same as they ever were. Not surprising, since the same folks who created the 80's TV series are strong forces behind these newer films (so, don't give me the "it's nothing like the 80's Chipmunks" routine, your hindsight is rose-colored). But, as usual, there are lessons to be learned here all around, and they are well done. It's a film about learning to be responsible when necessary, and parents learning to trust their kids when necessary (and that they've managed to teach them a thing or two), and even about learning to forgive and be a better person. Yeah, those are just a few lessons you can pull from this film, but it IS well done.

And, oh, did you know there's music in this too? Yeah, the Chipmunks sing a lot in this. Though, I think for some people this was still a weak point since the songs are mostly current (or recent), and not everyone keeps up with that stuff. I've heard some folks say they only recognized the first song in the film ("Vacation"), but I am sure that's not really true. Surely they recognize the Lady Gaga songs too, at the very least. Anyway, this was not a big issue for me, but I suppose a lot of the oldschool fans would like to see a few more oldschool tunes in any future installments.

"Alvin and the Chipmunks - Chipwrecked" is technically consistent with the 2 previous films. The visuals are highest quality, the characters are the same as we remember, and the story may be contrived for some, but as a chipmunks story it is fitting enough and makes way for the personality-driven entertainment, as a good, comedic cartoon plot should. Many will complain about the pop culture humor, especially the kind that panders to the youngest or that which some folks find tacky, but the Chipmunks are the very definition of pop-culture exploitation, let's face it. It's what they do. If you don't like it, watch something else. For the few moments of jokes that might leave older viewers clueless, most of the rest of the film is pretty universally understandable and entertaining, especially if you have been a fan of these characters for a looong time. Bottom-line, this is a fine Chipmunks movie. It's not as good as the first in this series, but that one focused the most on entertaining the oldschool fans. The sequels, yes, HAVE pandered more to the younger set (though at least they brought in the Chipmunks for us), but there is still plenty of fun and funny here, as well as consistency with the previous two films, that anyone who liked the other two should be able to enjoy this one too. It may be your least favorite, maybe not, but it's worthwhile if the Chipmunks are your thing, and if that isn't ONLY the 80's Chipmunks. Hey, I grew up with them too, I just think a lot of my fellow fans have that version on a pedestal. I think that's more the fault of the 80's bigscreen feature than the actual TV show, ha. Anyway, I do recommend this to those who saw the previous two. If you didn't, then why are you even here?

Now, a word about the Blu-Ray release. This Blu-Ray comes with a DVD and a digital copy. I don't use digital copies, so I won't talk about that. I think the DVD's are a nice inclusion, though if I'm paying more to get it, I'd rather just have the Blu-Ray and keep the price down. Anyway, there is a nice selection of behind the scenes featurettes here that talk a lot about the Chipmunks, the Bagdasarians (the family behind the Chipmunks), the film, and everything else. It's a kids movie at heart, don't get that wrong, but there's plenty of pop culture and internet culture references thrown in for good measure.  Theodore exclaiming over a double rainbow ("what does it mean?") and great chunks from the movie Castaway.  The music is poppy and entertaining and Alvin is up to his old tricks as usual (it wouldn't be a Chipmunk movie without him getting into trouble!) Jason Lee makes a good Dave, and has definitely got the "ALVIIIIN" yell down pat by now.

The story is predictable but not overly so, and has enough action and laughs to keep it flowing.  The movie never really bogs down, which is a good thing, and keeps at a nice pace, despite falling back on an overused shipwrecked type setting.  It's cute, inoffensive fluff that the kids will adore and the parents will tolerate.  Mine laughed through the whole movie, and yours probably will too.

The Alvin and the Chipmunks franchise isn't exactly held up as a paragon of contemporary cinema, but even for its low standards, its latest installment, Chipwrecked, failed on pretty much every level. In this third animated/live-action romp, the titular trio and their female counterparts are stranded on a deserted island when a parasailing mishap leads them astray; caretaker Dave and his old boss Ian work together to locate and rescue their furry friends. I found the film forgettable, with recycled humor and lazy writing that made for an obnoxious and unfunny moviegoing experience. But, as with so many movies of this nature, I must keep in mind that I am not the target audience here, and must concede that if you're just looking for something mindless to keep your very young children at bay for a couple of hours, this might do the trick.
